8.text:
It’s difficult to know much for certain
about the Chinese philosopher Lao Tzu.

12.text:
Even his name can be a little confusing; it
is also sometimes translated as Laozi or Lao Tze

17.text:
Lao Tzu is said to have been a record keeper
in the court of the central Chinese Zhou Dynasty

22.text:
in the 6th century B.C., and an older contemporary
of Confucius.

26.text:
He may also have been entirely mythical—much
like Homer in Western culture.

30.text:
Lao Tzu is said to have tired of life in the
Zhou court as it grew increasingly morally corrupt.

35.text:
So he left and rode on a water buffalo to
the western border of the Chinese empire.

40.text:
Although he was dressed as a farmer, the border
official recognised him and asked him to write

44.text:
down his wisdom. According to this legend,
what Lao Tzu wrote became the sacred text

48.text: known as the Tao Te Ching.

50.text:
After writing this piece, Lao Tzu is said
to have crossed the border and disappeared

54.text: from history, perhaps to become a hermit.

57.text:
In reality, the Tao Te Ching is likely to
be the compilation of the works of many authors

61.text:
over time. But stories about Lao Tzu and the
Tao Te Ching itself passed down through different

66.text:
Chinese philosophical schools for over two
thousand years.

69.text:
Lao Tzu was the leading figure in the spiritual
practice known as Daoism

74.text:
which is more than two thousand years old,
and still popular today. There are at least

78.text:
twenty million Daoists, and perhaps even half
a billion, living around the world now, especially

83.text:
in China and Taiwan. They practise meditation,
chant scriptures, and worship a variety of

91.text:
Daoists also make pilgrimages to five sacred
mountains in eastern China in order to pray

95.text:
at the temples and absorb spiritual energy
from these holy places, which are believed

102.text:
Daoism is deeply intertwined with other branches
of thought like Confucianism and Buddhism.

106.text:
There is a story about the three great Asian
spiritual leaders (Lao Tzu, Confucius, and

111.text: Buddha). All were meant to have tasted vinegar.

114.text:
Confucius found it sour, much like he found
the world full of degenerate people, and Buddha

118.text:
found it bitter, much like he found the world
to be full of suffering. But Lao Tzu found

122.text:
the world sweet. This is telling, because
Lao Tzu’s philosophy tends to look at the

127.text:
apparent discord in the world and see an underlying
harmony guided by something called the

133.text:
which describes the Dao, is somewhat like
the Bible: it gives instructions (often vague

138.text:
and generally open to multiple interpretations)
on how to live a good life. It discusses the

143.text:
“Dao” as the “way” of the world, which
is also the path to virtue, happiness, and harmony.

148.text:
"The way" isn’t inherently confusing
or difficult. But in order to follow the Dao,

153.text:
we need to go beyond simply reading and thinking
about it. Instead we must learn

159.text:
It’s a sort of purposeful acceptance of
the way of the Dao

162.text: and living in harmony with it.

164.text:
This might seem lofty and bizarre, but most
of Lao Tzu’s suggestions are actually very

168.text:
simple. First, we ought to take more time
for stillness. “To the mind that is still,”

172.text: Lao Tzu said, “the whole universe surrenders.”

176.text:
We need to let go of our schedules, worries
and complex thoughts for a while and simply

181.text:
We spend so much time rushing from one place
to the next in life, but Lao Tzu reminds us

185.text:
“nature does not hurry, yet everything is
accomplished.” It is particularly important

190.text:
that we remember that certain things—grieving,
growing wiser, developing a new relationship—only

195.text:
happen on their own schedule, like the changing
of leaves in the fall or the blossoming of

199.text: the bulbs we planted months ago.

202.text:
When we are still and patient we also need
to be open.

205.text:
“The usefulness of a pot comes from its
emptiness.” Lao Tzu said. “Empty yourself

209.text: of everything, let your mind become still.”

213.text:
If we are too busy, too preoccupied with anxiety
or ambition, we will miss a thousand moments

217.text:
of the human experience that are our natural
inheritance. We need to be awake to the way

220.text:
sounds of the birds in the morning, the way
other people look when they are laughing,

224.text:
the feeling of wind against our face. These
experiences reconnect us to parts of ourselves.

229.text:
This is another key point of Lao Tzu’s writing:
we need to be in touch with our real selves.

234.text:
We spend a great deal of time worrying about
who we ought to become, but we should instead

238.text: take time to be who we already are at heart.

242.text:
We might rediscover a generous impulse, or
a playful side we had forgotten, or simply

246.text: an old affection for long walks.

249.text:
Our ego is often in the way of our true self,
which must be found by being receptive to

253.text:
the outside world rather than focusing on
some critical, too-ambitious internal image.

257.text:
“When I let go of what I am,” Lao Tzu
wrote, “I become what I might be.”

262.text:
Nature is particularly useful for finding
ourselves.

265.text:
Lao Tzu liked to compare different parts of
nature to different virtues. He said,

270.text:
"The best people are like water, which benefits
all things and does not compete with them.

274.text:
It stays in lowly places that others reject.
This is why it is so similar to the Dao."

280.text:
Each part of nature can remind us of a quality
we admire and should cultivate ourselves—the

284.text:
strength of the mountains, the resilience
of trees, the cheerfulness of flowers.

289.text:
Of course, there are issues that must be addressed
by action, and there are times for ambition.

293.text:
Yet Lao Tzu’s work is important for Daoists
and non-Daoists alike, especially in a modern

298.text:
world distracted by technology and focused
on what seem to be constant, sudden, and severe

His words serve as a reminder of the importance
